intro: Qualea lineata, commonly known as the water lily of the Amazon, is a tropical aquatic plant native to the wetlands of South America. It is characterized by its broad, floating leaves that form a dense surface layer on the water, providing habitat for various aquatic organisms. The plant produces small, white flowers that bloom above the water surface, typically during the dry season. Its roots are anchored in the mud at the bottom of the water body, allowing it to thrive in still or slow-moving waters. Qualea lineata plays an important role in maintaining water quality and supporting biodiversity in its native ecosystems.
